title: 115_s1777
content: The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes an excise tax on corporations with low-wage employees under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers who employ low-wage employees based on the aggregate amount of wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" refers to those required to make tax deposits under chapters 21 and 24 of the Internal Revenue Code. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers who must make tax deposits under chapters 21 and 24 of the Internal Revenue Code, excluding governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers who must make tax deposits under chapters 21 and 24 of the Internal Revenue Code, excluding governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. The term 'low-wage employee' is defined as any employee who receives wages. Aggregation rules from section 414 apply, with 'more than 50 percent' substituted for 'more than 80 percent'. The term 'low-wage employee' refers to an employee earning less than 218 percent of the Federal poverty line. Rules similar to section 36B(d)(3)(B) apply. Employees employed for less than a full year by an applicable taxpayer will have the amount described in subparagraph (A) reduced based on the ratio of weeks not employed to 52 in the calendar year. The applicable percentage for determining employee benefits is based on a ratio to 52 in the calendar year. The applicable employee ratio determines the percentage for employee benefits as follows: 25% or less = 25%, greater than 25% but not greater than 50% = 50%, greater than 50% but not greater than 75% = 75%, greater than 75% = 100%. The low-wage employee ratio is calculated as the percentage of low-wage employees to total employees for an applicable employer. This ratio is used to determine the health and retirement offset for employees. The applicable employer's health and retirement offset can be reduced by 25 percentage points if they offer full-time low-wage employees the opportunity to enroll for all months during the calendar year. Employees (and their spouse and dependents) have the opportunity to enroll in minimum essential coverage under an eligible employer-sponsored health plan for all months during the calendar year, where the plan's share of allowed costs is at least 60 percent and the required contribution is met. The eligible employer-sponsored health plan must cover at least 60 percent of costs and the employee's contribution should not exceed a certain percentage of their annual wages. The plan must also meet retirement plan requirements for low-wage employees. The retirement plan must meet requirements for low-wage employees, with the applicable percentage determined by section 36B(c)(2)(B)(II) for the plan year. Eligibility for participation in applicable eligible plans is essential for low-wage employees. The retirement plan must meet requirements for low-wage employees, with the applicable percentage determined by section 36B(c)(2)(B)(II) for the plan year. Eligibility for participation in applicable eligible plans is essential for low-wage employees, who must be eligible to participate in one or more applicable eligible retirement plans maintained by the employer for a plan year ending within the calendar year. An applicable eligible retirement plan is defined as an eligible retirement plan that is either a defined contribution plan. An eligible retirement plan must meet requirements for low-wage employees, with the employer making nonelective contributions of at least 5 percent of the employee's compensation for defined contribution plans or ensuring that the accrued benefit from employer contributions in defined benefit plans meets certain criteria. The annual retirement benefit must meet certain criteria, including a contribution of at least 2 percent multiplied by the employee's years of service with the employer or 20 percent multiplied by the employee's final average pay. The retirement benefit calculation involves a contribution of at least 2 percent multiplied by the employee's final average pay. The retirement benefit calculation requires a pay credit of at least 5 percent of compensation in an eligible retirement plan as defined by section 402(c)(8)(B). The retirement benefit calculation requires a pay credit of at least 5 percent of compensation in an eligible retirement plan, such as a simplified employee pension (as defined in section 408(k)). Final average pay is determined using the period of consecutive years with the greatest compensation from the employer, not exceeding 5 years. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for alternative plan designs for applicable employers. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for applicable employers to meet retirement benefit requirements through a combination of defined contribution or defined benefit plans. Plans must meet requirements without considering social security contributions and benefits. The regulations for retirement benefits for applicable employers may exclude certain employees based on age and years of service. Employees may be excluded from retirement benefits if they have less than 1 year of service, are covered under a collective bargaining agreement, or fall under specific criteria outlined in section. Employees may be excluded from retirement benefits if they have less than 1 year of service, are covered under a collective bargaining agreement, or fall under specific criteria outlined in section 410(b)(3)(C) for nonresident aliens working outside the United States. Definitions and special rules regarding wages and tax allocation are also provided in this section. The Secretary will allocate the tax imposed among entities treated as a single employer. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Chapter 37--Corporate Responsibility Tax. The amendments made by this section apply to calendar years after the enactment of this Act.
